What is the best way to encode parameter interdependendence in a Turing. ? E.g. paramerter bounds are dependent on a second parameter. The parameter part of my models looks like this at the moment, basically just rejecting any sample which doesn't satisfy the conditions by add `-Inf` to `logprob` but that doesn't seem a particular efficient nor elegant way of doing it.

```@model function _turing_model(data::NamedTuple, ode_prob::ODEProblem, solver, priors::NamedTuple, sim::Bool=false, logp::Bool=false; ode_args = (;))
	### priors
    p_preDCbm ~ priors.p_preDCbm
    p_cDC1bm ~ priors.p_cDC1bm
    p_cDC2bm ~ priors.p_cDC2bm
    δ_preDCb ~ Uniform(0.0,2.0)
    λ_cDC1 ~ Uniform(0.0,2.0)
    λ_cDC2 ~ Uniform(0.0,2.0)
    Δ_cDC2bm ~ Uniform(0.0,2.0)
    Δ_cDC2b ~ Uniform(0.0,2.0)
    σ1 ~ TruncatedNormal(0.0, 1.0, 0.0,Inf)
    σ2 ~ TruncatedNormal(0.0, 1.0, 0.0,Inf)
    σ3 ~ TruncatedNormal(0.0, 1.0, 0.0,Inf)

    λ_preDC = (Δ_cDC2b + δ_preDCb) / data.R.RpreDC

	### parameter constraints
	if p_preDCbm ≤ (λ_preDC + Δ_cDC2bm)
		Turing.@addlogprob! -Inf
		return
	elseif λ_cDC1 ≥ p_cDC1bm
		Turing.@addlogprob! -Inf
		return
	elseif λ_cDC2 ≥ p_cDC2bm + Δ_cDC2bm * data.R.RpreDC_cDC2_bm
	 	Turing.@addlogprob! -Inf
	 	return
	end

    ### compound parameter
    δ_preDCbm = p_preDCbm - λ_preDC - Δ_cDC2bm
    δ_cDC1bm = p_cDC1bm - λ_cDC1
    δ_cDC2bm = p_cDC2bm + Δ_cDC2bm * data.R.RpreDC_cDC2_bm - λ_cDC2
    δ_cDC1b = λ_cDC1 * data.R.RcDC1
    δ_cDC2b = λ_cDC2 * data.R.RcDC2 + Δ_cDC2b * data.R.RpreDC_cDC2_blood

    ### parameter vector
    theta = [p_preDCbm, δ_preDCbm, p_cDC1bm, δ_cDC1bm, p_cDC2bm, δ_cDC2bm, δ_preDCb, δ_cDC1b, δ_cDC2b, λ_preDC, λ_cDC1, λ_cDC2, Δ_cDC2bm, Δ_cDC2b]

...
end```
